PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

(Debate on the Address)
(Second Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [13th January, 1994],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mr Loh Meng See].

    Question again proposed.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, one major factor for Singapore's success is our ability to learn from the experience and expertise of other nations. We formulated our policies by combining the good points that we have learned and avoiding the pitfalls that we have seen. Today, we have evolved a uniquely Singaporean system which others are now learning from us, because of our success. Our system is one which emphasises competition based on market principles to maximise results but maintains a strong sense of cohesion and fairness. This balance between competition and cohesion is the basis for a dynamic, just and progressive society. It underpins the principles, policies and methods in all our Government functions, be it education, health care, workers' welfare, housing or transportation. It seems to me that this is perhaps the only model that will prevent wealthy nations from declining which we have seen it happened too often in history.

    So if Singaporeans want to have more of the good things in life, they will have to compete to get them. This is the only way. But as competition becomes more intense, and as differences of achievements become more stark, greater efforts will be needed to maintain cohesion.

    The cohesion which we have developed among our people over the last 30 years has also enabled us to compete better against other nations. In our country, the Government works with the people. In our companies, the management works with the unions and the workers, and among the people, different races work in

Column: 113

harmony. All these may not be true in other countries. So we need to maintain this advantage. The question is: how? Maintaining cohesion requires the effort of everyone -the Government, the employers, and the people.

    The Government has done well to provide equal opportunities for every citizen to learn, to compete and to succeed in life, and a safety net to those who need it. It has also started an asset enhancement programme for Singaporeans. However, the Government could do more to strengthen its bond with the people. This can be done through paying more attention to the feelings of Singaporeans when implementing policies. While it is true that Government has always considered a wide range of reasons before deciding on a policy, it must remember that the ordinary citizen does not have the same perspective and he usually looks at it narrowly from his point of view. There must therefore be proper explanations, consultations and discussions to see whether any genuine problems, however small, can be resolved.

    A case in point is the recent changes in medical benefits and salary revisions for public sector employees. Up to today, there are still some unresolved issues. For example, if we accept that those who opt for the Co-payment on Ward Charges Scheme should forgo their salary revision this round, why should they be denied future revisions? There is also the unresolved issue of whether there should be a minimum increase of salary in dollar terms. How can the offer be attractive to some officers if it works out to be just $20-$30 a month?

    Under the Comprehensive Co-payment Scheme, while it is true that MediShield can help look after the co-payment when one incurs a substantial hospital bill, very few people understand fully how it works. Some workers have enquired at the CPF, but their apprehensions have not been removed because of the complexity of the scheme involving limits to daily charges and operation charges, etc. The Government should come out with the improved

Column: 114

MediShield as quickly as possible and as simple as possible, and explain what a patient can expect from his bill with the intended lowering of deductibles and limits.

    Sir, for employers, I believe that they must also do likewise. There should always be consultations and discussions before any policy of the company is implemented because workers do not usually see it from the management's point of view. As for the people, they need to be more objective in their criticism of Government policies. I have held discussions with many of my friends, many of whom are professionals and highly intellectual people, but I can observe that they do not see things as widely as they should. They look at it usually from a narrow angle and sometimes their views are coloured by their own personal interests.

    Take the case of COEs (Certificates of Entitlement), for instance. Today, many still argue that since we have COEs, we can take away all the other taxes in the form of ARF, road tax, and so on. They think that because we have COEs to control the number of vehicles, it alone should therefore work. But they fail to understand that if you do that, then all the savings that you can have from other taxes like ARF will be transferred to the prices of COEs. In the end, who is going to suffer? The people who buy smaller cars are going to suffer. Why? Because at the moment the ARF works against those who buy huge cars. When a person does not have to pay his ARF any more, and assuming he is buying a big car, the amount that he saves would naturally be transferred to his bidding in order to ensure that he gets a COE. But there is no guarantee that he will get a COE. If he does not get a COE, of course, in the last resort, he will downgrade to a lower category. When that happens, the people who are bidding in the slower category will lose out. In the end, you will find that you have a situation where the COE prices could become unmanageable and those who intend to renew their COEs after 10 years would find it too expensive to do so. By spreading these taxes across-the-board on a number of measures, it is obvious that the situation is more manageable.

Column: 115



    I am just giving examples to show that Singaporeans must also take note of their biases and that they should try to find out more for themselves the reasons why a particular policy is implemented. I believe that cohesion is the key for us to continue to have intense competition and progress economically. But unless and until all three parties - the Government, the employers and the people of Singapore - realise their roles and understand that they should not always insist on their views, we will not be able to continue with our objective of generating wealth through competition in a sustained manner.

    On the subject of the Minimum Sum Scheme, I support the scheme because I can see the problem coming. There are many people who now retire without enough cash and it is very difficult for them to sell away their house. Even if they do so, I have seen many cases where their cash quickly disappears because of demands from family members, relatives, friends and so on. We need to have the Minimum Sum Scheme in place and we also need to ensure that there is enough cash when the people retire so that they could continue to enjoy a decent living. But we need to be careful on how we implement the scheme. At the moment, we have a Special Account in our CPF and we can use this Special Account to form part of the cash requirement in the Minimum Sum Scheme. But we should not force people to cough up cash to top up to the amount that we think is necessary because, if we do so, there will be people who will find it difficult to meet the requirement.

    With these remarks, I support the motion.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you very much for allowing me to join in this debate.

    Sir, the most significant event which has direct impact on the Singapore economy in 1993 is the successful conclusion of the Uruguay round of GATT. The last-minute packaging of the Uruguay round in time for the fast track approval by the US Congress has given Singapore some

Column: 116

breathing spell in its ability to compete in a free and fair trading world. In fact, Sir, ironically, the impetus to the conclusion of GATT came not from a belief in free trade per se but from a growing fear of regionalism, tribalism and the formation of trading blocs. GATT was concluded in the shadow of NAFTA and the US threat of retreating from Europe into the embrace of APEC. In other words, the world is at once becoming more global because of GATT, and more local because of all the regional groupings. Singapore must therefore operate within this new world order.

    The President is right to urge Singaporeans to work overseas, to venture abroad, to be more internationalist, because obviously that is where the markets are. But at the same time, the President has exhorted us to be more Singaporean to face the world as one people.

    What did the President's Address touch on? He touched on many issues. But to me, the basic message is that the world has changed. So some policies must keep pace with these changes like, for example, we are all living longer, and the demographic pattern is changing. So I think it makes sense to secure our retirement by keeping more money in the CPF. We should all support the proposed revision to the CPF Minimum Sum Scheme. I think some of this should be in cash because when we retire we may have our HDB flats, but we cannot eat our assets even though we may enjoy in their comfort.

    Sir, change is frightening. It will always be resisted. That is why we must reaffirm our commitment to the tripartite arrangement between all three parties - the Government, the management and the union. We must work together to explain the need to change and cushion some of the harsher impact of some of the new policies to come. For example, some policies that are good are not very clearly explained. Dr John Chen, my colleague, has already pointed out some of these policies. It does no harm for me to repeat in a different manner what he has just said.

Column: 117



    The new health care policy to be put in place is a welcome one. But some schemes, like the co-payment scheme, the MediShield scheme, are not very clearly explained to the ordinary man-in-the-street. I was just told this morning that one civil servant went to the CPF Board to collect some MediShield forms. The counter staff told this civil servant that there was no need to apply. Why? He was told MediShield does not apply to civil servants. This is wrong because MediShield is a safety net for all of us who have not opted out. I think such simple policies which we all need to know in very clear simple terms are not made explicit to some of the counter staff, some of the civil servants. The task of explaining the new impact of new policies should be the task of Government, employers as well as the unions. I think I need to repeat this point because in the last few months many new policies have come on stream. Some are very difficult and complicated policies that cannot be made too simple, yet we must try to make them simpler.

    The President has told us that some things have changed. So we must respond quickly. But the President is also telling us that some things should not change and must not change, things like family values, using the free market to drive the economy or tempering the system with a compassionate hand and avoiding the welfare trap that has impoverished once proud and rich nations.

    Sir, the apparent collapse of the Russian free market system has renewed protectionist voices to stop the free market from rolling on. But in fact, on closer analysis, the biggest mistake Gorbachev has made was to liberalise prices before breaking up the monopolies of cartels which had dominated the Soviet economy. But at that time, of course, Gorbachev's hands were tied because he needed to fill the shelves with goods very quickly. But critics of the free market should look to China to see the success of the system there. They cannot be so dense to ignore how much happiness, how much joy, how much prosperity, the free market has brought to the Chinese.

Column: 118



    Sir, the free market is the final arbiter of who earns high income, who earns low income. The market is not the best judge, but in an imperfect world like ours, the market offers the least imperfect solution. Sir, we should never envy the rich remisiers or the rich estate agents because they earn more money than some of us. Everybody likes to talk about them these days because we have just experienced the crest of a property and stock market wave, notwithstanding the fact that in the last few days it has gone down. But when the market crashes, who cares about these remisiers and property agents. We should never be so arrogant to assume that street-smart people have low IQs. Indeed, I have a university colleague, a Ph.D in Electrical Engineering or in Mathematics - I cannot remember - who resigned from his job as a lecturer to become an ordinary real estate broker. I do not know about his IQ, but if you equate degrees with IQ, I think his IQ cannot be so low.

    Sir, the President's call to reaffirm our future in a free market is correct. It is an unbiased system, not the fairest, but the best available so far. It is therefore refreshing to hear the President play new music and sing familiar old songs. It is this constant fine-tuning of old policies and steadfast adherence to the basics that will secure our future in the 21st century. Sir, we should never need to go back to the basics, something which John Major is urging the British to do so, because we should never leave the basics.

    Sir, for all the things the President has said, to my mind, the most important message is the one embedded in the last paragraph. If I may quote from the Address, the President said:

    "So long as we are prepared to learn and to work our best, we can continue to be ahead. But we need the cohesion and determination to excel. Then we will thrive and prosper."

    Sir, the key word in this paragraph is "cohesion". How do we tackle the issue of cohesiveness? Indeed, what is cohesiveness and whether it is at all necessary. Dr Wang Kai Yuen is concerned that with the growing income gap there will be less cohesion, all things being equal among Singaporeans. Over the last 10 years, the

Column: 119

income gap in Singapore has naturally narrowed, but in the future there is indeed a danger that the gap will widen. But this is not because the Government is skewing the salary structure to reward the rich. The real reason why income gap will grow in the future is because the world is becoming more global, more porous and, sooner or later, borderless. The mercantilist days where labour was only mobile within national boundaries are over. So are the unskilled who will have to compete with the unskilled in China, in India and in Mexico, to manufacture the same product.

    It is also naive to assume that a lesser income gap will make a nation more cohesive. If it were so, the experience in China and elsewhere is instructive. With a porous world economy, a widening income gap is, as I have said, inevitable. Robert Reich devoted a major portion of his book, The Work of Nations, to explaining why nobody can stop this phenomenon. The alternative is, of course, equality of income where everybody is equally poor. Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Robert Reich is a Democrat whose whole life has been devoted to narrowing the income gap. He has told the Americans in no uncertain terms that the income gap will widen and he cannot stop it.

    Before China opened up her closed economy, there was equality of income. Everybody was equally poor, but were they happy? I do not think so. Now, in China, the income gap has really widened. The rich and the poor are quite obvious. I can tell you, Sir, that not all are happy. I think most are happier. In fact, Jiang Zemin, at the 14th National Congress, told the Chinese that they must widen the income gap so that everybody will become more prosperous. So the challenge is really to accept this inevitable outcome and build social cohesion around the growing income gap. One way is to structure policies and programmes so that everybody, including the lower income group, is better off with the new policies than with the old policies. We would have succeeded, Sir, so long as our poor is richer than the rich elsewhere. I think that is the key - so long as our poor is richer than the rich elsewhere.

Column: 120



    The Japanese have shown us what cohesiveness is and what it can do for the society. Japan always has income inequality. The rich eat gold-plated leaves, the poor sleep in the subways. Sir, you and I do not see the destitutes in Japan so easily because they move into the subways after the last train has rolled off and they clear up quickly before the first train rolls in. It is wrong to conclude that cohesion in Japan is weak in spite of this income gap. The Japanese are a cohesive lot and with it they have leap-frogged from a poor, underdeveloped country into the ranks of the G7 - the club for the richest in the world. But luckily for the Japanese, cohesiveness comes easy because Japan is a very homogenous society.

    I learn recently that new Japanese expatriates in America were astounded by the fact that Americans greeted each other on the streets, even among strangers, "Good morning, Sir", "Good afternoon" and "Good day". Sir, the need to appear polite and reassuring, I am told, is not of paramount importance in Japan. Why? Because apparently in Japan they are so homogenous that they know their feelings every morning, every afternoon, every evening. I think this must be an exaggeration. But it says something about the Japanese culture and their cohesiveness. If nothing else, they think they are alike. That is important.

    Unfortunately, Sir, Singapore is not a homogenous society and it will never be. We are a land of immigrants consisting of Chinese, Malays, Indians and others. Instead of this inherent natural cohesiveness, the possibilities of friction and conflict are enormous. Even within the same ethnic groups, many of us have different loyalties. Sir, Japan did not become a developed nation because of the plurality of individualism and a diversity of opinions, and neither will Singapore. But can Singapore follow Japan's footstep to become the second country to leap-frog from the ranks of the very poor into the ranks of the very rich? I think we are very close to there, but we are not quite there yet. I think we are 10 to 15 years behind the very rich. In order to reach that position, the club of the very

Column: 121

rich, the G7, or the G8 eventually, we need a goal, we need a mission, we need a purpose, we need an objective, to work as a team. But right now, what is that mission? We have "Vision 1999", and we have several other missions. We have this national ideology being toyed around.

    To me, Sir, our mission must be to fulfil our forefathers' dream of making it big in Singapore. When our forefathers came to Singapore from afar and braved the unknown seas, they came with visions of hope, they came with dreams of finding that pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. We are almost there, we are very close to it, but we are not quite there yet. We can do it all together if we heed the President's call for more cohesion.

     Mr Chay Wai Chuen (Brickworks GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to speak in support of the motion of thanks for the President's Address.

    Sir, the President's Address has correctly identified one of the most glaring problems in our society, that of the ageing population. Closely tied to this is the problem of health care for the aged. It is reassuring to hear that the Government is looking into this problem now, although it is a problem more of the longer term. The President's Address mentioned that it will raise the Minimum Sum in the CPF gradually and will decide in the next few months which is the best way to do so. I think there is very little choice in this matter. People's life expectancy is longer these days and good public health has lengthened the people's life span. $36,000 may be able to buy an annuity for about $300 per month for perhaps 15 years, depending on the interest rate. However, that is very unlikely to provide a very decent livelihood at today's cost of living. Hence the amount for such a livelihood provision has to be higher. Whilst we can sort out the arithmetic and decide on the increase in the Minimum Sum, the section of the people who will be affected by this would be those who are currently working. For the other section of the people who have already retired long ago and who have limited savings, it is a struggle to make ends meet. Many of

Column: 122

them, especially in the lower income bracket, cannot rely too much on their children to support them fully because their children also have families of their own, and these children also need to be provided at today's cost of living.

    Sir, in my first speech in Parliament in January 1989 I had addressed this issue. I had also urged the Government to adopt policies which can allow our elderly to achieve more financial security and flexibility. At that time I had urged the Government to examine a reverse mortgage scheme for the elderly who own HDB flats. Two of my colleagues had also made the same point yesterday. Under this scheme, an elderly couple who own a HDB flat can reverse mortgage the flat for a stream of income payments by the HDB or a properly constituted re-financing body for a term period. In this way, the couple can still remain in their flat but at the end of the term period they would no more own their flat. In the meantime, they receive a stream of income for their livelihood. Then at the end of this term period, they can rent the flat from the HDB possibly.

    Sir, this proposal was first made in the Howe Yoon Chong Report. I think there are many good suggestions in the Howe Yoon Chong Report on the Aged which we should study deeply for implementation. Unfortunately, it was torpedoed prematurely, and we all know the history of it.

    I urge once again the Government to examine this policy. Many aged Singaporeans in HDB flats own only one asset - their flat. Some viable way can be found to liquidate this saving. This reverse mortgage proposal is much better than asking them to sell off their flats and move into rented ones. Over time, through this reverse mortgage instrument, the HDB can acquire back the flats for redevelopment or for rental. And the cycle of life savings for many Singaporeans can then be better deployed for their needs and the needs of society.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion in the name of Mr Loh Meng See.

    We should be proud to be Singaporeans. The unrivalled success of our

Column: 123

tiny island nation has assured us a place in history. We can list all the advances we have made in our economic and material progress and these indicators continue to impress the rest of the world. The sceptics have been converted.

    The President in his Address said:

    'Our short term issues are well in hand. My Government's focus is therefore on long term policies to position ourselves for the next stage of nation building.'

    It is therefore time for us again to look at ourselves and examine our ethos and our values and our responsibilities towards some long term trends in our country.

    Mr Speaker, our supreme goal cannot just be the quantity of money we have, our GDP and our rate of economic growth. What should matter as well is the quality of our life and the morale of our society. We will have to address these long term concerns if we are to continue as a successful and cohesive society.

    If we do not, crass materialism will take over resulting in the breakdown of our values of motivation, self-regulation and self-awareness. In the quest for material gains, there is the tendency to believe that nothing succeeds like excess. Lavish dinners, flashy new cars, expensive club memberships, branded goods and excessive consumerism cannot sustain for long the spirit of our people.

    Unfortunately, at this stage, we and our youth seem to be vigorously aspiring only towards these material goals. Most of us try to achieve these with hard work. Others have already begun the downhill slide where the end justifies the means.

    Let me give you the sorry example of some young women whose material cravings have persuaded them to offer sex for sale in order to sustain a high spending life. This was reported in our media. We also hear of some other young people who have been devoting their energy and time to making money single-mindedly at the stock market at the expense of their study and even work. Community and public service is the last thing on their mind. Who are the role

Column: 124

models for these young men and women? People whose worth is measured in dollars and practically nothing else.

    Economic success is of course of paramount importance to Singapore and has brought about considerable economic security, happiness and social development but the danger now, Mr Speaker, is to see most things in terms of only dollars and cents - we know the price of most things and the value of very few. The ethos of this world view was captured well by a Straits Times journalist under the caption: "No Money No Talk".

    Well, we have to talk about this aspect of our lives now. We have to put the economic imperatives at the upper end of our scale of priorities but not as the raison d'etre of our lives. If we do so, then after the initial euphoria of monetary rewards, there will be a backlash. Remuneration alone cannot continue to motivate people and money cannot buy happiness. After a certain period, money can, if misapplied, kill a worker's desire to do his or her best. According to the work of dozens of social scientists, when we do something only for monetary reward, we tend to become less interested in what we are doing.

    Besides our growing obsession with material success, there are other long term concerns that will affect the future of our nation and, Mr Speaker, I am going to address them under three headings: active citizenship, family values and old age security.

Active citizenship

    The Prime Minister has expressed his concern over the reluctance of people to take up positions in the political arena. This is a serious worry. How do we overcome this?     Mr Speaker, we have talked endlessly about the importance of family and how it forms the basic building block of society. We have also talked about what we do not want in families, that is, divorce and single parents.

The term "single parenthood" covers a variety of social situations - from the unmarried young mother to the middle class divorcee and the middle-aged widow. All these single parents cannot be tarnished with the same brush. It is the illegitimacy rate and the children born out of wedlock that give rise to the attendant culture of welfare dependency, crime and social despair. Many children in single parent families, for

example, children brought up by widows often do better than those in two-parent families.

    (1) Social stigma.

Some of these families (about 4,000 in number) live below the minimum household expenditure, that is, a family of four living in a 1-room flat with a disposable income of $510.     (4) the Small Families Improvement Scheme should be extended to some deserving families where the fathers have deserted the family.

Old Age Security

    Now, Mr Speaker, I shall speak on old age security. According to the CPF Board, members retiring at 60 who have contributed continuously for their full working lives (which is about 35 years) at the rate of 40% of net wage can expect a

Column: 130

retirement income of 20% to 40% of the last take-home pay, a property commensurate with their income level and health care under the Medisave scheme. This augurs well for the young generation and, therefore, we will not have to worry in the future for the young people who are in the labour force today.

    However, for those of us who were over 20 in 1975 (and I am one of them), we will not be able to meet even the modest levels of retirement benefits estimated by the CPF Board. This is because before 1975, the CPF rate on net wage basis was below 40%. It has been estimated that in the year 2015, those over 20 in 1975 will constitute 0.6 million people which will add up to about 20% of the population.

    Also, there is a gender difference in CPF balances. For women below 45 years of age in 1989, average balances were closer to that of their male counterparts. After the age of 45 onwards, males have nearly twice the CPF balance as compared to the women. For the present cohort of women aged 55 and over, they may face financial difficulties in old age, given the average low CPF balances they and their spouses have. This situation will become accentuated with time as women are expected to outlive their spouses by at least five to eight years on the average.

    According to one estimate, Mr Speaker, in the year 2000, which is not too far away, 19% of men and 34% of women reaching 60 years of age will not have any CPF to depend on. A report by the Advisory Council on the Aged puts the figures much higher.

    At the present time, according to one estimate, about 20% to 25% of the people in the labour force are not covered by the CPF scheme. A certain proportion of those not covered, that is, unpaid family workers, contract workers and some of the marginal hawkers are likely to be faced with inadequate resources to finance their old age. Thus, for the next 15 to 20 years, we will have an interim situation where old age security is not assured. This applies to the older men and women, the poor self-employed and home-based workers. We have to make provisions for

Column: 131

this fairly serious social and economic situation. The recommendations that the Government should consider are:

    (1) Compulsory gradual CPF contributions for all self-employed.

    SAF scholars tell me that every few years there is a shift in the values, the ambitions, the expectations of the younger SAF officers. They want it faster and quicker. And because the upper ranks are now being filled by fellow SAF officers, no longer the old regulars who are easy to replace, but people of the same calibre, the progression up is slower, and the attrition rate must be higher, and we accept that. So what I am saying is a system that we worked in the 1960s and 1970s, we could no longer work

Column: 160

in the 1980s, and they would be stupid if they did not make amendments, and sometimes radical changes, to meet the circumstances of the 1990s.

    I will recount to you what has happened to countries that do not make this adjustment, that make believe with the past.

    I know Britain best because we inherited our system from them and I spent so many years studying there, negotiating with them for our independence and having a lot to do with them even after independence. In their system they pay their Ministers a token. The practice was: you go into politics only if you have inherited private wealth, then you are a country gentleman, you can afford politics. And when you take office, it is for the honour of it, and honourable men sacrifice their personal interests for the sake of the nation. Of course, the sacrifice was never severe because of their private incomes. And there is a club, an informal network that exists in Britain's club land, that leads to the city, that leads to mutual benefits. Now, few in Britain have private incomes, and this has created problems for them. And their editorial writers and their city analysts write in despair of the quality of their Ministers. Three-quarters of them, sometimes more, they say, of their Cabinet, could not find a top job in a multi-national. They are just dismissed. They can do it, they can get away with it. It is a different system. It is well established. The country would not collapse. But Singaporeans are not in that position to take liberties with the system.

    We have to insist on honesty and competence in the men and women who take charge of government in Singapore. In other words, we must elect such people into Parliament. And Singaporeans must resist a world trend of falling standards in politics. It is a world trend.

    By the 1980s I had decided that the British system would be more disastrous for Singapore than it had been for Britain. So I broke away from the old policy in 1984, when I increased Ministers' pay to 80% of their private sector counterparts at that time. I followed this up in 1989 when the Prime Minister, then as First Deputy Prime Minister, announced that the Prime

Column: 161

Minister would have the right to pay a Minister make-up pay of up to 90% of his pay in the private sector. This was just to give myself scope in case I was unable to recruit men of quality, then I had to co-opt somebody right from the top to fill a job for three, four, five years, because I needed a top executive for a specific job in a specific time.

    Those of you who have watched the British TV series "Yes, Minister" and its sequel "Yes, Prime Minister" know that it portrays a popular, probably mistaken, view that any ordinary guy can be a Minister because the real job is done by the Permanent Secretary. The series exaggerates the real Minister-Permanent Secretary relationship in Britain. But let me assure you that in Singapore, such a series would not be funny.

    From the very start of Ministerial government in 1955, that was before my time, that was my first election to the Legislative Assembly at that time, and Mr David Marshall and then Mr Lim Yew Hock became Chief Ministers in turn, the British government recognised that the British system could not be reproduced in Singapore's different circumstances. We have no political class with inherited private incomes. Singapore needed Ministers who have the ability to make their way in this world, earn their living, and earn a good living, and be capable to take charge of a Ministry. And we must continue to select Ministers who are better than their Permanent Secretaries. Even when we cannot succeed for each Ministry, the Ministerial team, as a team, must be stronger than the Permanent Secretaries' team. Otherwise the creativeness, the boldness in making sweeping changes necessary from time to time to meet changing circumstances and to seize opportunities will be missing because the Permanent Secretary is, by his training and by his mental approach, someone who attends to the details and goes for incremental improvements.

    I will list the items which would never have happened without Ministerial direction. The practical bilingual system of education - it works. Many paid a

Column: 162

heavy price in the early days when the system was pitched too high. Either you got too much Chinese or you got too much English. And those who had too much Chinese found themselves, after Nanyang University, with poorly-paid jobs. We had to bring about an answer to it, an answer which had to be politically acceptable. We would never have gone into independent or autonomous schools. No Permanent Secretary would want to think of it. It creates problems for him. Nor would we have restructured hospitals, nor would we be here with Medisave instead of a burgeoning medical services budget. I foresaw this in the 1970s and I blocked into Special Account 4%. That was the beginning of Special Account. We sat down, we discussed this, and said this was coming to us, let us not go in for this buffet syndrome.

    I remember one Minister, one of my colleagues, furiously disputing my policy. He had just come back from China and he praised the system where from top to bottom they all had the same free medical services. Those were the days when we believed what we were told, that everybody had the same medical services. Fortunately, the pragmatists carried the day and we avoided this. And we certainly would not have COEs, we would have traffic jams today. Nor would we have HDB homes for 90% of the population. No Permanent Secretary thought it out, no housing authority specialist thought it out. We thought it out. We were determined to do it because we had to have a national service army to fight, and nobody is going to fight for somebody else's Takashimaya, Ngee Ann City, or Cairnhill condominium. He must have his stake, and we created that stake.

    Now the Prime Minister has carried it forward with an asset enhancement programme, which means every surplus will be distributed not to finance expenditure but to increase your assets. And if you want to spend it, you sell it, and have the satisfaction of your consumption at the cost of diminished assets. You calculate. Would you spend it if it is your money and not the taxpayer's, meaning somebody else's money? We are giving it to you, spend it, if you will. And it is very

Column: 163

instructive. When you give it to them, and it is theirs, a whole mental approach changes.

    If you look at governments around the world where the Ministers are weaker than their Permanent Secretaries, those governments lack lustre. When I was a student in Britain in the 1940s after the war, the first choice of the best graduates of my generation was to go into the professions and go into Parliament. The top students aimed for it. It was a glorious period in British parliamentary history. Young men had come back, bright, able young men who had risen rapidly up the ranks in the war. People like Ted Heath had come back as Brigadier, Enoch Powell, Dennis Healey came back as Major, and their younger officers got scholarships or paid-for free university and wanted to emulate them. They wanted to change and build a better world and the best headed for politics. The second choice was the civil service and the top branches were the Treasury or Finance, and the Foreign Office. Today, I ask my friends who are now teachers at the University: what is the choice? This was a few years ago, and he said banking and financial services. The city of London first, because that is where the big rewards are, the big banks. Then the professions and the civil service. Politics is not the top choice. It is not among the top choices of the brightest and the best. More and more it is for the second best, for those who can talk their way out of their inadequacies, or think they can.

    There is a similar situation in America and I read this in yesterday's International Herald Tribune (IHT). It is the Op-Ed page, an article by Charles Peters, who is Editor of The Washington Monthly and he wrote this for The New York Times. He deplored a dearth of talent in government, and by this, he meant not just people who are elected to Congress, but people hired by the government. First column, second last paragraph:

    'December began with the announcement that two senior members of the White House staff, Roy Neel and Howard Paster, were leaving for lucrative jobs in the private sector. Those jobs would permit them to cash in on their connections in a way the administration had once promised would not be tolerated. [Remember the last elections, none of these lobbying and cashing in on connections.] Yet they departed with the president's praise.' says Mr Charles Peters.

Column: 164

And he goes on in the third column:

    'There has long been a shortage of qualified people in government, a deprivation that is now especially severe amongst Democrats, who have been out of the White House for all but five of the last 25 years. It is a grave problem in a society that has too long undervalued public service.

    Only during the New Deal and the New Frontier [New Deal was Roosevelt, New Frontier was John Kennedy] was there a major effort to bring the most talented citizens to Washington. [When you bring talented citizens to Washington, then you get an efflorescence, new ideas.] The result is that far too many of the people experienced in government are mediocre. The most glaring deficiency of Al Gore's "Reinventing Government" report was its failure to recognize this quality problem. [Al Gore, as you know, is the Vice-President.]

    According to the Volcker Commission [Paul Volcker was one of the top bankers who was in charge of the Federal Reserve at a very difficult time in the Carter and Reagan period.] on the Public Service, 90 percent of college honor students do not even consider a career in government.'

    In the American system, an honours student is someone in the top 5% of a graduating class, then you get either summa cum laude, magna cum laude, or Phi Beta Kappa, whatever it is. 90% would not even consider a government job. I mean that is how lowly paid it is, how lowly rated it is, and the country pays a price for it. They all want to be lawyers, or lobbyists. I think the problem is not going to go away and it is better for us to understand how the market works. Because once upon a time, I did not understand it. So forgive me if I assume that some of you may also not understand it!

    I have been encouraging the Prime Minister to take a strong and realistic position on the pay of Ministers, judges and civil servants because they are all connected. You go up Superscale, then you go up staff grade, you go up to judges, you go up to Ministers. That is an escalation ladder. Then you end up with the President at the top of the pyramid. The decision, of course, is his, as it must be, because it is a politically important issue. His job is to ensure that for the next 10 to 20 years, in a very different climate, a different economic and social climate, the best will still join the Government, and not just for short periods, not one of these turn-around jobs where having made all the right friends in the right places, then

Column: 165

you are off to run your practice with all the right contacts and private telephone numbers.

    Ministers have always been paid more than judges who, in turn, are paid more than civil servants. And you know a good lawyer naturally wants to be a judge rather than a Minister, and I know that. The higher pay for a Minister does not make up for the change in lifestyle, the publicity, the criticism and the demands of public office.

    Once upon a time, as a young undergraduate, I believed that vast pay differences between the incomes of professionals, bankers and the average worker was unjust and unnecessary. That is why I became a socialist. Some countries actually applied their moral value judgment and translated it into practice and decided that Ministers should not earn more than 25 times the lowest paid. And this was so in China, where Chairman Mao earned, in money terms, not more than 25 times the lowest paid worker in China. Of course, that is the money reward. If you include his different housing, servant, food, travel and health services, then you may come up with a different equation. But anyway, the theory is, we will all wear Mao jackets. But let me tell you this. Some Mao jackets are fur-lined. One Minister who was travelling (this was before the kai fang zhengce ) said, "It was very cold." He said, "That's all right." He unbuttoned it, and inside it was fur. It was the same outside, dull blue or dull grey, but he was a comfortable man.

    Let me add when my education began. It was after I had to start to earn a living, not as an assistant in a firm where I was paid a salary, but when I became the employer and I had to pay the rent, furnish the office, hire clerks, get a library and worry about where the income was going to come from to pay for all these. Then I began to understand the law of supply and demand, and over time, I concluded that prices and wages and differences in pay are necessary if you want people to put in their best. I realised that fairness is a question of relativity. In the end, I concluded that moral values on pay are

Column: 166

good only for textbooks on socialism and political tracts on social justice, in other words, when you talk about metaphysical things, not about the real world.

    Boris Becker, I watched him win the Wimbledon championship at the age of 17, that is umpteen years ago, and he earned in that one year from his prize money and his endorsements for tennis rackets, shirts, bands, shoes, whatever, more than $10 million, a bigger sum than any talented surgeon or lawyer in Germany would earn after many years of specialised training and experience. What sense does it make? Ask yourself, morally - what sense does it make? Supposing Boris Becker had been a table tennis champion, instead of a lawn tennis champion, would he have earned half a million dollars? Where are the followers? The followers are poor people with low incomes in China and Southeast Asia. The viewers who will buy all these beautiful branded goods are in America, Europe and Japan and they do not want to watch table tennis. You see two chaps prancing around and you cannot see the ball. Nobody wants to pay you any money for the TV rights. Lucky if you can make $50,000.

    It is the supply and demand for tennis players that determine the winnings of champions and the winnings that they make, in turn, decide the supply of new champions. And because the rewards are so great, all the top athletes in Europe, America, Australia and New Zealand aim to be tennis champions, not ping-pong champions, or gymnasts. There is a constant flow of them and they come in younger and younger, faster and swifter, because they have been sucked into it by the enormous prizes you get when you reach the top, and they spend prodigious efforts to get there, to satisfy the millions of tennis fans in the wealthy countries. Supposing China became wealthy and they still like ping-pong, then you might get people wanting to be ping-pong champions. But I have a feeling that when China is wealthy, they will also go in for tennis which costs more than ping-pong.

    So in the same way for soccer, or golf, and one of our Ministers, who is connected with football, said to me, "Ah,

Column: 167

Fandi, we pay him $100,000." That, for Singapore, is a very big prize. But he said it is worth it because he brings in the crowds. If you want to understand the market, leave aside your moral values and ask yourself: Why did this happen?

    I take another example from doctors. A first class pathologist, or haematologist, or paediatrician earns less than an average gynaecologist or a surgeon. They all pass through the same medical school. Why? It is supply and demand. To be a surgeon, you need very good dexterous fingers, quick mind. I had this explained to me by our former Speaker, who was a good friend of mine, why not every doctor can be a good surgeon and why some people should be forbidden from being surgeons at all because they are butchers. So I ask myself: why do people then want to be a pathologist, a haematologist or a paediatrician? Is there any justice in this? You get this argument in the university and it goes on interminably. I had it over the last 30-odd years and I am tired of it. If you pay that for a Professor of Gynaecology, you pay me the same because I am a Professor. I am a pathologist. But what is the opportunity cost? You can go. I will look for another pathologist. I can get him anywhere. All the chap has got to know is some pathology and the students will pass. Anyway, young women and their husbands will pay for a good gynae-specialist. That is all. It is as simple as that.

    Kandang Kerbau Hospital has seen a tremendous drop in patients. Because they are young, they've got their Medisave, they choose the best. I am not sure it is wise but that is their choice. So there is really no abstract just or fair relationship between ability and rewards. The real relationship is between supply and demand for these three specialists. And when the economy goes wrong, as it is during a transition in China, a taxi driver or a barrow boy selling fruits or chestnuts earns more than a university professor. Because one is stuck to his renminbi, fixed salary, the other is dealing with tourists who come in with US dollars, Deutschemark, Japanese yen, Hong Kong dollars or Sing dollars. But in the end, will the taxi driver earn more? Because you can have any number of people becoming

Column: 168

taxi drivers. And in the end, when you have an ordered state of society, students want to learn, not everybody can be a professor. So it will find its balance.

    When the Government announced the gross salaries of the Prime Minister as $96,000 a month and Ministers at $64,000 a month, astonishment and shock, surprise. Why so large? These are gross salaries. The base pay for the Prime Minister is $45,867 and for Ministers, there is a range between $26,932 and $33,261. Because we live in this computer age, adjustments are made in percentage terms and the figures are not rounded off. The total remuneration includes all annual bonuses: the 13th month Annual Wage Supplement (you all get it in your computer printout with your allowance), 2 months of Annual Variable Component, 2 months of tax free car allowance, imputed income tax on this car allowance which does not apply to non-Ministers, plus an estimated 4 months of Performance Bonus.

    This total remuneration is not an automatic flat payment. A significant part, about one-third, is conditional because the Annual Variable Component goes up or down depending on the state of the economy and it can be reduced or cancelled in a recession. And we deliberately move to follow the market. It means, for Ministers, that the Performance Bonus can vary between 0-6 months, depending on the PM's assessment of a Minister's performance. Ministers are not equal. We do not come through sausage machines. Ministries are not equal. In my time, I looked at the Minister, then I decided how. First, I looked at the team and I judged realistically what each member of that team can carry. Then I load the heavy jobs on the Ministers with the broad shoulders. If you do not do that, then you will be in trouble. Never give a Minister more than his shoulders can carry.

    One-third, therefore, is variable and performance related. And the NWC's guidelines say one-fifth, 20%, but we keep it variable up to one-third.

    I believe this matter should be got out of the way by settling a formula for Ministers

Column: 169

and top civil servants, linking their pay to incomes in the private sector, so that there is no need to come and justify a salary revision every three or four years. Adjustments can then be made automatically based on IRAS figures. They come in every year. Inland Revenue gets it. The formula can be worked out and it will go up or down with the private sector, and never get seriously out of line.

    One possibility is to peg the pay of the Prime Minister to the income of bankers, say, 80% of the average of the top three or four bankers in Singapore. Ministers' pay can then be pegged to the PM's, ranging from 60% to 70% of the PM's, which I think is over generous, but never mind.

    Banking is a good approximation to the work of a Prime Minister. The CEO of a bank has to judge which enterprises are viable and credit worthy, which economic sectors are at risk. A bank's business covers all sectors of the whole economy of a country. So when the economy goes down, the bank must go down. When the economy flourishes, the bank must flourish. And the PM's work also covers the whole economy, plus political, security, social, educational, cultural, all sectors of life.

    The disadvantage, of course, of pegging the PM's salary to bankers alone is that the comparison is only with a few individuals in the private sector. So an alternative would be to peg the PM's pay to the earnings of top professionals in a representative range of companies. For example, we could peg it to the average earnings of the top three or four men in each of six professions. The top three or four average of six groups: bankers, lawyers, engineers, accountants, MNC manufacturers and local manufacturers, as for the permanent secretaries. These are professions where general management and leadership skills, and not just specialised technical expertise, are important. And they will give a broader basis for comparison.

    Singapore has a rising economy in a booming region. This region will boom for another 10-20 years, at least. The total pay

Column: 170

for all Ministers, Ministers of State, Parliamentary Secretaries for 1993 was $14 million. After the revision, it will be $18 million. So when we get excited about this, please remember it is $4 million. One word from the Minister in Kuala Lumpur, the stock market went down by a few billion Ringgit. So keep a sense of perspective. It is 0.74% of $2.4 billion which is the wages of all the Government employees. And remember this is an economy which last year had a GDP of $84 billion and will increase by another 6-8%.

    Real estate agents get 2% on every deal. If I were a young man again and I was choosing my options, I would consider coming into politics if you would pay me 0.002% of the GDP to be Prime Minister. Then I will take it on. So have a sense of proportion.

    Do not believe that you will find them like pebbles on a beach. If we do not get the best into political office in Singapore, we will become like any one of those countries where voters change bumbling governments regularly, every three, four, five years, always in the hope of finding something better, but inevitably, getting disappointed. And with this will come a deadly disease of money politics.

    Marcos earned US$5,000 a year. You convert his pesos into US dollars, it was US$5,000. I calculated all this some years ago for the sake of a debate here. His progeny, according to the Philippines government are worth anywhere between $5-$10 billion. But the country has been cleaned out and it is in debt to the tune of $29 billion. That's for getting a President at US$5,000 a year, paid in pesos.

    But when we talk of the euphemism of money politics, we are really glossing over something much more profound, much more disconcerting. It is money and politics, which are found in many countries, mostly developing and some developed. When candidates invest large sums of money to get themselves elected, either to a party and then to Parliament, when they get into office, they must get the expenses covered. Because an investment has been made, the expenditure you put down in the loss account.

Column: 171

So you must have an income account. And not only must you cover the expenditure to make the venture worthwhile, you must also build up a credit for the next round. After you have done that once or twice, you say, well, there will come a day when you are not going to contest any more, so you must have a retirement fund. And in the end, you end up, as was discovered, with gold bars, share scrips, cash and so on when they raided the home of a respected LDP leader called Shin Kanemaru. Or you end up with Aldo Moro, former President of Italy, many many times, now facing serious charges that he was linked up with the Italian Mafia.

    So far, Singapore has succeeded in being different and this is in spite of constant exposure to money and politics. Singapore businessmen do business in these countries and have to abide by the local rules. But if they come back and bring those local practices from elsewhere into Singapore, we would lose a vital competitive advantage, which will do grievous harm to our economy. One reason why we are what we are is because of this competitive advantage, and corruption will do grievous harm to our lives. Corruption has destroyed many developing countries in Asia, Africa, Latin America and it has severely damaged developed countries like Italy and Japan. Because the best have not gone into politics, the results have been bad for these developed countries.

    Over the last ten years there has been growing disillusionment, especially in the United States and the United Kingdom, with politicians. Opinion polls show the public's ever lower opinion of politicians, MPs and Ministers in Britain, or Congressmen and Senators in America. I do not want to be accused of passing judgment myself. So I will read what Neville Stack, who writes for a British paper, and who also gets carried in the Business Times of 7th January, 1994, says. He says that the polls say that the people rate politicians way down with used car dealers for their "trustworthiness and veracity." It is because of their lack of honesty, especially in their political campaigns, and the ease with which they abandoned their political

Column: 172

platforms after they have been elected, that is also losing them respect. To make money, Ministers and politicians keep diaries so that they can sell gossip and scandal by writing books when they are out of office, and earn big money through serialisation in the newspapers.

    I ask you to remember a very simple rule of thumb. If you want good government, you need good leaders. You do not get good government by just a good system of government. That is a fallacy. Even in the best of systems, if the leaders in charge are bad, the government will be bad.

    When the best have not gone into politics, the system has always worked poorly, malfunctioned. This has been the case in America and in Britain for some time. People in America and Britain are growing disillusioned with their systems. Because it does not work, they start finding fault finally with the system because they toss out one, they try the other, it does not work. So they say, "Well, the system is at fault. Let us change it. From first-past-the-post to proportional representation, we will have coalition governments like the Europeans, then we may be all right." It is funking reality. The reality is, your system does not attract honest and able men to take on the job. The result is the second best. The result is second rate performance.

    There was an essay in Time magazine. This is just the last few days which also made me decide to intervene in this debate. As I was reading the monthly magazines and the weeklies in the newspapers, it occurred to me that perhaps I should share some of my thoughts with Members of this House. I have one advantage in that nobody believes that I am calculating for the next 10, 20, 30 years. I want to leave behind something, which I hope will be useful to you in your job because you have to look forward to the next 10, 20, 30 years.

    This essay was by Michael Kinsley and he described the dilemma in America in an essay entitled "Is Democracy Losing Its Romance?". It is in the Time magazine of 17th January, 1994. It is in the second last

Column: 173

page. He explains why the democratic system has not delivered. This is one of the honest pieces. Because the litany, the mantra, has been: you have democracy and you have the free market, you will be like America. It is not true. You look at Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union or the Russian Republic. I will just read one paragraph, the third last paragraph of this thoughtful piece where he admits it is not working:

    `Even in the heartland of "traditional" democracy, the United States of America, there are whiffs of disenchantment. The "populism" surging through American politics these days has a certain antidemocratic flavor. Or, at least, it reflects a resentment of democratic institutions and procedures. "Washington" [those who comprise Washington politics] and politicians have replaced "Wall Street" and rich businessmen as populism's favorite targets. The favorite populist remedies - congressional term limits, a balanced-budget amendment - would be new constraints on democracy. And, like earlier versions, today's populism hungers for a strong leader on a white horse. Thus Ross Perot, America's would-be Fujimori.'

    They are tired, tired of lies, tired of broken promises, but, at the end of it all, tired of the lack of progress in their lives. Their problems are not being solved because they are going through the motions of democracy. You have committees, you have this, you pass legislation, you block each other. It is a game. If we play those games here, we are finished. These are established societies. Ours is not. The disillusionment in Britain is even deeper. I have not read the full editorial, but this editorial in the Daily Telegraph was picked up in the IHT, 12th January, 1994, that is two days ago. It is entitled "Alas, a Sorry Tory Lot."

    'In the eyes of the public, the government appears increasingly mired in sleaze. The only regret displayed by ministers for public or private lapses from grace concerns their loss of office, not the actions which caused it. We have a Tory Party apparently incapable of shame. Conservative MPs and parliamentary candidates today are, for the most part, a sorry lot. A generation ago, Central Office and constituency parties decided to turn away from selecting candidates of "traditional" Tory backgrounds. [He puts in quote "traditional". That means the class that has supplied this kind of people as MPs.] The products of Eton and the squirearchy found themselves spurned. Perhaps it was right to seek a new style of Tory MP. But what has emerged, in place of the old knights of the shire, is a host of frankly inadequate men and women who, far from entering Parliament in any spirit of public service, are driven solely by the pursuit of self-advancement.'

Column: 174



    If that had come from a Labour Party paper, I would have understood it. But the Daily Telegraph is Britain's most consistent Tory newspaper. It believes in conservatism. It has stood by the Tory Party. It is holding up its hands in despair. But long-established democratic constitutional systems have institutions which are cherished in the hearts of their people and therefore can command their loyalty even when they do not approve of the leaders who are temporarily in charge. So countries like America and Britain can recover without serious damage if and when good leaders replace the poor ones.

    A bad system will not have this strength to survive bad leaders. Bad leaders are usually overthrown in a coup or a revolution and the next leader inevitably changes the system again, never establishing anything more enduring in the hearts of their people. And that is Africa. They are always going through some change. You change the name of the country from Equatorial Africa to some historic name in some distant past and hope you will leave the bad luck behind. But it is not established in the minds of the people. Because we do not have a long-established democratic constitutional system of government and if institutions are not rooted in the hearts of the people for them to respect whoever wields power through those institutions, the consequences for us can be dreadful with bad leaders.

    Because we dreaded these consequences, following a decline in standards of Ministers, my older colleagues, Dr Goh Keng Swee, Rajaratnam, Lim Kim San and I, broke away from the conventional practice of choosing election candidates and Ministers from the activists who had joined us. Had we continued that conventional system, the history of Singapore would be different and you would not be here, and Singapore would not be this kind of a place. Instead we went out to recruit the best of each year's crop regardless of their politicals ideology, dogma, or philosophy. We looked for people, first, with a good character. That is the first qualification. What is the character of the man. Second, a good mind. We ignored whether a man or

Column: 175

woman was critical of the PAP or against some of our policies. We were confident that a sound person would logically come to only a few alternative solutions once he applies his mind to the problems that we face, because we do not have such a wide margin for experimentation. As we renewed the team of MPs in Parliament every four years, we improved on the selection process. But even with the most careful of selection procedures, the attrition rate was high, at first about 30%, later 20%. It is a tough system.

    It is one I helped to build and it will be painful to see it falter. But it is foolish to believe that good men in Singapore will naturally go into politics.

    The original team was fortuitous, a fluke, if you will, or a stroke of destiny. But that old guard exerted strenuous efforts to get together the present team.

    There are many political parties in Singapore. They regularly contest elections. But apart from the Communist Party of Malaya and the PAP, in Singapore no party has ever got together a team of substantial men or leaders who are credible because in Singapore society, well-educated and upright men and women with promising alternative careers do not go into politics.
